item.title: The Political Scene | The New Yorker
item.description: Despite his failed bid for Speaker, the Ohio representative is the face of a Republican Party that is more interested in launching investigations than it is in passing laws.

item.title: Soundcheck
item.description: Pianist Pascal Le Boeuf combines backgrounds in jazz and electronic music, and brings a hybrid piano trio with strings to play high-energy music from his album 'Ritual Being', in-studio.

item.title: Brian Lehrer: A Daily Politics Podcast
item.description: One of the key witnesses to President Trump's role in the Jan. 6 insurrection has a new book.

item.title: New Sounds
item.description: Paul Simon presents Seven Psalms, a guitar-based song cycle of musings on life and death, faith and technology - and explains the adapted instruments and textures involved.

item.title: Young Artists Showcase
item.description: Julian Rhee joins host Chee-Yun Kim in the studio for a program of Wagner, Tchaikovsky, and Saint Saens.

item.title: On the Media
item.description: It's been weeks since we've had a House Speaker. How did we get here?

item.title: Brian Lehrer: A Daily Politics Podcast
item.description: What made people believe the "American Dream" when the myths around it came about, and where is that sentiment left in 2023 and beyond?

item.title: New Sounds
item.description: Hear works with orchestras deployed in untraditional ways in music by American composers Viet Cuong (with wine glasses), Robert Moran (in the round), and John Luther Adams (outdoors.)

item.title: Gig Alerts
item.description: The California Honeydrops play rootsy music that might sound like everything from soul and R&B to New Orleans second-line music to ska to blues. They play at Webster Hall on Oct. 25.

item.title: Notes from America with Kai Wright
item.description: We hear from Osage tribal members about building on the momentum from the release of Martin Scorsese's, Killers of the Flower, to revitalize Fairfax, the town where the film is set.

item.title: Brian Lehrer: A Daily Politics Podcast
item.description: We discuss how the conflict in the Middle East intersects with the GOP's fight over who the new Speaker of the House will be.

item.title: New Sounds
item.description: Hear music with a minimalist sense of motion, all featuring reed instruments, in music by producer/composer Akusmi, English composer Poppy Ackroyd, and American minimalist Steve Reich.

item.title: The Political Scene | The New Yorker
item.description: This week, President Biden made a diplomatic visit to Tel Aviv, and sought aid from Congress for both Israel and Ukraine.

item.title: Brian Lehrer: A Daily Politics Podcast
item.description: Hamas is still holding an estimated 200+ people hostage after a large-scale offensive last week.

item.title: Gig Alerts
item.description: Turtle Island Quartet plays music by Terence Blanchard, Jerod Impichchaachaaha' Tate, Rhiannon Giddens, and by the quartet’s founder Balakrishnan at Alice Tully Hall on Oct. 27.

item.title: Gig Alerts
item.description: English hip hop musician Loyle Carner raps about family life, food, soccer, poetry, the weight of being Black in modern Britain. He performs on Oct. 26 at Irving Plaza.

item.title: Gig Alerts
item.description: Montreal-based singer, author, composer, and multi-instrumentalist Arielle Soucy writes gentle, dreamy songs that draw on psychedelic folk with occasional touches of soul or pop.

item.title: Gig Alerts
item.description: Cameroon-born songwriter Vagabon makes "music for outcasts" and wants "to feel safe and at home in my body and in my mind". She plays at Music Hall of Williamsburg on Oct. 24.

item.title: Weekend Edition Saturday
item.description: A look at how New York's leaders have responded to the conflict.

item.title: On the Media
item.description: Steady descent into the fog of war; the deadly challenges of reporting from Gaza and Israel.

item.title: New Sounds
item.description: Hear prepared piano, prepared guitar and prepared trumpet from Maurice Louca, prepared Sardinian guitar by Paolo Angeli, and prepared kantele (Finnish folk harp) by Pauliina Syrjälä.

item.title: New Sounds
item.description: There's music by polyphonic choir Zedashe Ensemble, microtonal jazz by Giorgi Mikadze with Georgian choir Ensemble Basiani, and Georgian songs arranged by Evan Ziporyn and Kate Bush.

item.title: New Sounds
item.description: From the annual Ojai Music Festival, listen to members of AMOC play music by violinist and composer Andrew McIntosh (of the band Wild Up); and music from bass-baritone Davóne Tines.

item.title: New Sounds
item.description: Hear music from ensembles Sybarite5, Turtle Island Quartet, The Jupiter & Jasper Quartets, and violist/composer Jessica Pavone’s string ensemble marking women-made inventions.

item.title: Brian Lehrer: A Daily Politics Podcast
item.description: The the editor-at-large of Jewish Currents argues for Palestinian liberation through non-violence, taking lessons from the successes and failures of South African resistance movements.

item.title: Soundcheck
item.description: German singer, composer, and actress Ute Lemper defies expectations with original songs on 'Time Traveler', which embrace pop, jazz, soul or chanson. She and her band play in-studio.

item.title: The Political Scene | The New Yorker
item.description: The New Yorker reporters David Kirkpatrick and Adam Rasgon, who recently spoke with a political leader of Hamas, discuss the group's decision-making and evolution.

item.title: Young Artists Showcase
item.description: Host Derek Wang presents the Aspen Contemporary Ensemble live from the Aspen Music Festival.

item.title: On the Media
item.description: Is the analogy useful to understand what happened, or what comes next?

item.title: Brian Lehrer: A Daily Politics Podcast
item.description: In today's installment of our monthly "Call Your Senator" discussion, NY's junior senator explained how she thought about the US's involvement in the Israel-Hamas war.

item.title: New Sounds
item.description: Hear music drawing on Medieval and Renaissance sources by Irish soprano Caitriona O’Leary and Anakronos, Ukrainian sound artist Heinali, the Hilliard Ensemble with Jan Garbarek, & more.

item.title: New Sounds
item.description: Listen to songs that hope, imagine, and wish for, or are about peace in work from Scottish guitarist Sean Shibe, Montréal’s Black Ox Orkestar, and Kenyan sound artist Nyokabi Kariuki.

item.title: Carnegie Hall Live
item.description: Hear Gateways Chamber Players' performance at Carnegie Hall on Sunday, October 22.

item.title: New Sounds
item.description: There's choral music inspired by folk songs and European religious sites by Estonian composer Veljo Tormis, English composer Joby Talbot, and Canadian Indigenous composer Jeremy Dutcher.

item.title: Notes from America with Kai Wright
item.description: Leo takes his influence beyond the courtroom to society and politics more broadly.

item.title: Brian Lehrer: A Daily Politics Podcast
item.description: A Palestinian affairs analyst explains some of the long-standing internal politics of Gaza and the West Bank, including Hamas, Fatah and what has prevented a two-state solution.

item.title: Notes from America with Kai Wright
item.description: How can we have a more honest conversation about security, war, and peace in the region?

item.title: Brian Lehrer: A Daily Politics Podcast
item.description: There's so much nuance and context behind the situation between Israel and Hamas, which often gets drowned out by emotionally charged discourse.

item.title: The Political Scene | The New Yorker
item.description: In this bonus episode, the hosts of Critics at Large dissect Walter Isaacson’s new biography of Elon Musk.

item.title: The Political Scene | The New Yorker
item.description: When an outrageous yet charismatic candidate for president promises to kill suspected criminals, reporter Patricia Evangelista says, we should listen: it may not be just a talking point.

item.title: Soundcheck
item.description: Irish singer/songwriter CMAT knows how to take a deep dive down a topical rabbit hole and make it into relatable pop. She plays songs from her latest, 'Crazymad, For Me', in-studio.

item.title: Gig Alerts
item.description: Singer, rapper, and writer Dessa has made a career of bucking genres and defying expectations. Her new album, Bury The Lede, is out now, and she plays Oct. 20 at Le Poisson Rouge.

item.title: Gig Alerts
item.description: Pianist, composer, and singer Amina Claudine Myers has worked with both the Art Ensemble of Chicago and Henry Threadgill, and plays the Blues. She's part of BRIC JazzFest, Oct. 19-21.

item.title: Gig Alerts
item.description: English singer and songwriter Charlie Cunningham touches on classic jazz, flamenco, and Nick Drake. He plays his intimate and intricate songs at Bowery Ballroom on Oct. 18.

item.title: Gig Alerts
item.description: Singer/songwriters Julien Baker, Lucy Dacus, and Phoebe Bridgers also work together as boygenius. In addition to their full-length, their latest EP is 'The Rest', containing "Powers".

item.title: Gig Alerts
item.description: New York-based discodelic band Say She She (Yes! after the band Chic), perform their sugary harmonies, disco-grooves, and dance moves at Bowery Ballroom on Oct. 17.

item.title: New Sounds
item.description: Hear the influence of folk music associated with Appalachia and the British Isles, in music from Ireland’s Dave Flynn, Michigander Laurel Premo, and New York-based bassist Devin Hoff.

item.title: New Sounds
item.description: Hear ambient and post-classical works by Belgian violinist/violist Catherine Graindorge, Norwegian bassist Jo Berger Myhre, French composer Odalie, Berlin-based Nils Frahm, and others.

item.title: New Sounds
item.description: From the 2022 Ojai Music Festival, hear bass-baritone Davóne Tines and members of the American Modern Opera Company perform work by the spiritual and provocative composer Julius Eastman.

item.title: The New Yorker Radio Hour
item.description: The legendary filmmaker makes the case for his unconventional memoir. Plus, the fallout from the “kill them all” drug policy in the Philippines.

item.title: Trump, Inc.
item.description: Reporters Andrea Bernstein, Ilya Marritz, and Andy Kroll bring you Episode 3: The Federalist Society for Everything

item.title: Notes from America with Kai Wright
item.description: Leonard Leo cultivates wealthy donors, and a fishing trip sets off a Supreme Court ethics scandal.

item.title: New Sounds
item.description: Listen to an hour of music inspired by or built directly on Indian ragas in work by the California-based Alaya Project, Brooklyn Raga Massive, and dhrupad singer Wasifuddin Dagar.

item.title: On the Media
item.description: The initial surge of war misinformation was even worse this time around.

item.title: The Political Scene | The New Yorker
item.description: Reporting from Tel Aviv, Ruth Margalit discusses Hamas’s massacre of Israeli civilians and Netanyahu’s siege of Gaza.

item.title: Brian Lehrer: A Daily Politics Podcast
item.description: In the days since Hamas stormed past Israeli security checkpoints and began the deadliest stretch of violence in the reason since 2014, questions have emerged about the US's role.

item.title: New Sounds
item.description: Listen to bronze, glass, bicycle wheels, and ice - in work by Andy Akiho and the Omaha Symphony, Aizuri Quartet playing Lembit Beecher, and gamelan-influenced work by Zemi17.

item.title: Young Artists Showcase
item.description: Host Ed Yim presents the Juilliard School’s 2023 Gina Bachauer Competition Winners, Jack Gao and Ryan Zhu.

item.title: Ask Governor Murphy
item.description: “I firmly believe that when all the facts are presented, not only will I will be exonerated but I still will be New Jersey’s senior senator,” Menendez has said.

item.title: Brian Lehrer: A Daily Politics Podcast
item.description: Over the weekend, Hamas launched an unprecedented attack on Israel’s border with Gaza.

item.title: On the Media
item.description: Leo's vision for American society .... collides with American society.

item.title: Soundcheck
item.description: Milwaukee singer and guitarist Buffalo Nichols further draws the past into the present on his latest, 'The Fatalist'. He plays these blues songs for the present, in-studio.

item.title: New Sounds
item.description: Hear music that considers the tangled roots of Black Music in the Americas from multi-instrumentalist Jake Blount, Haitian-American Leyla McCalla, and Congolese-Canadian Pierre Kwenders.

item.title: Death, Sex & Money
item.description: The filmmaker behind HBO’s How To with John Wilson shares how his hobbies, like checking Craigslist ads obsessively, make him feel more deeply connected.

item.title: Brian Lehrer: A Daily Politics Podcast
item.description: What's Congress's role in the nation's foreign policy regarding the violence in Israel, particularly as the House is mired in a GOP leadership fight?

item.title: Soundcheck
item.description: Classically-trained Two-Spirit song carrier, composer, activist, and Member of the Wolastoqiyik People of the Neqotkuk, Jeremy Dutcher, plays new music with a trio, in-studio.

item.title: Gig Alerts
item.description: Brooklyn Raga Massive offers their 24 Hour Raga Festival, featuring "In E Half Flat", by Iraqi-American musician Amir ElSaffar, starting at 8PM on Oct. 14, at Pioneer Works.

item.title: Gig Alerts
item.description: The Handsome Family (Brett and Rennie Sparks) bring gothic American roots music to White Eagle Hall in Jersey City on Oct. 12, and to Public Records in Brooklyn on Oct. 13.

item.title: Gig Alerts
item.description: The songwriter, pianist, vocalist, and producer Raia Was has become known for her dark art-pop. She presents work from her latest, 'Captain Obvious' on Oct. 11 at National Sawdust.
